abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Eleventh Railway
            Project for Pakistan was unsatisfactory. The project did not
            achieve its main objectives and was not completed, its
            impact was very modest, sustainability is not likely, and
            the Borrower performed less than satisfactory. However, the
            Bank performed its duties satisfactorily. Several lessons
            can be learned from this project. First, in retrospect, the
            Association was overly optimistic about how quickly the
            railway management could begin to respond to the challenge
            of road competition. As such, it might have been better to
            delay appraisal until it was clear that the Railway Board
            understood the need for adjustment and was willing to take
            appropriate measures. Second, regarding the implementation
            of the major project components, the results would have been
            more satisfactory had the necessary PC-1 documents been
            approved before project effectiveness. This approval should
            be a prerequisite for project effectiveness. Lastly,
            compliance with certain covenants in the Credit Agreement
            was too little and too late. Some of the requirements of the
            covenants and the Plan of Action called for measures that
            invited reaction from local politicians. These measures were
            essential given the rapidly growing deficit and need for
            financial discipline.
